title: 103_hr3810
content: The Act titled "Rural Community Wastewater Treatment Affordability Act of 1994" is referred to as the short title. Eligibility criteria are outlined in Section 2. Section 2 of the Rural Community Wastewater Treatment Affordability Act of 1994 expands eligibility criteria for acquiring lands, easements, and rights-of-ways necessary for construction of treatment works. It also includes provisions for rural nonprofit water associations to receive assistance for wastewater treatment and water supply services. SEC. 3. CAPITALIZATION GRANT AGREEMENTS. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to encourage the use of innovative technologies in treatment works construction. SEC. 4. TYPES OF ASSISTANCE. The Loan Program under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including interest free and negative-interest loans, with terms not exceeding 40 years or the useful life of the project. The Loan Program under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including interest free and negative-interest loans, with terms not exceeding 40 years or the useful life of the project. The terms for loans to rural and disadvantaged communities should not exceed 40 years or the useful life of the project being financed. The Loan Program under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at terms not to exceed 40 years or the useful life of the project being financed. Additionally, not more than 15 percent of all loans made from the water pollution control revolving fund will be allocated after the enactment of this amendment. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allocate up to 15 percent of loans from the revolving fund for negative-interest loans to rural and disadvantaged communities. Additionally, planning grants to disadvantaged communities are also addressed in the amendment. The enactment of this subparagraph allows for negative-interest loans to rural and disadvantaged communities. Planning grants to disadvantaged communities are also included in the amendment, covering up to 75 percent of planning and predevelopment costs. The amendment allows for grants to rural and disadvantaged communities to cover up to 75 percent of planning and predevelopment costs for treatment works without the requirement of actual construction. The grants shall not be less than 1 percent and not exceed 2 percent of Federal grant awards. The amendment allows grants for rural and disadvantaged communities to cover planning and predevelopment costs for treatment works without requiring actual construction. Grants must be between 1-2% of Federal grant awards and not exceed $75,000 per project. The amendment allows grants for rural and disadvantaged communities to cover planning and predevelopment costs for treatment works without requiring actual construction, with a maximum grant amount of $75,000 per project. The definition of "rural and disadvantaged communities" is based on the service area of a publicly owned treatment works as defined by the concerned State. The term 'rural and disadvantaged communities' refers to service areas of publicly owned treatment works defined by the State, excluding areas with a population over 10,000 and residents with a household income exceeding 75% of the national median. The term 'negative-interest loan' refers to a loan with a zero percent interest rate provided by a State to rural and disadvantaged communities, where the State forgives up to 2 percent of the loan principal. A 'negative-interest loan' is a loan with a zero percent interest rate provided by a State to rural and disadvantaged communities, where the State forgives up to 2 percent of the loan principal annually, not exceeding a total forgiveness of 20 percent over the loan term. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS amended to limit costs to 4 percent of total funds deposited into the fund. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE introduces a grant program for technical assistance. The Administrator may provide grants to organizations for training and technical assistance to rural communities on treatment works. $15,000,000 per fiscal year is authorized for this purpose until 1998. A conforming amendment is made to Section 607 of the Act. Authorization of $15,000,000 per fiscal year for training and technical assistance on treatment works until 1998. Amendment made to Section 607 of the Act.
